name: Animals of desire and danger
blurb: Gazelle and stag (agility/desire), foxes (small threats to vineyards), doves (beauty/faithfulness). Creatures voice love’s energy and vulnerabilities.
searchText: animals of desire and danger group imagery gazelle and stag (agility/desire), foxes (small threats to vineyards), doves (beauty/faithfulness). creatures voice love’s energy and vulnerabilities.

name: Brothers of the Beloved
blurb: Guardians of her honor who made her keep the vineyards; later negotiate protection for a younger sister—family structures that both constrain and care.
searchText: brothers of the beloved group family guardians of her honor who made her keep the vineyards; later negotiate protection for a younger sister—family structures that both constrain and care.

name: Companions/friends of the bridegroom
blurb: Listeners near the couple’s garden; wedding-feast echoes; community delights in private joy without intrusion.
searchText: companions/friends of the bridegroom group chorus listeners near the couple’s garden; wedding-feast echoes; community delights in private joy without intrusion.

name: Daughters of Jerusalem (chorus)
blurb: Choral companions who hear, question, and witness—liturgical audience framing love’s pedagogy. They receive the refrain ‘Do not awaken love until it pleases.’
searchText: daughters of jerusalem (chorus) group chorus choral companions who hear, question, and witness—liturgical audience framing love’s pedagogy. they receive the refrain ‘do not awaken love until it pleases.’

name: Fragrance, oils, spices
blurb: Nard, myrrh, frankincense, saffron, cinnamon, aloes—olfactory worship of love; sensory theology of delight.
searchText: fragrance, oils, spices group imagery nard, myrrh, frankincense, saffron, cinnamon, aloes—olfactory worship of love; sensory theology of delight.

name: Place-names & landscapes (En-gedi, Sharon, Tirzah, Jerusalem, Lebanon, Hermon, Amana, Senir)
blurb: Geography becomes metaphor—strength, fragrance, fertility, majesty; love roams Israel’s map as temple-garden renewed.
searchText: place-names & landscapes (en-gedi, sharon, tirzah, jerusalem, lebanon, hermon, amana, senir) group place geography becomes metaphor—strength, fragrance, fertility, majesty; love roams israel’s map as temple-garden renewed.

name: Watchmen of the city
blurb: Public order figures: once helpful in her search; later violent guardians who beat and strip her—ambivalence of societal gatekeepers over intimate love.
searchText: watchmen of the city group civic public order figures: once helpful in her search; later violent guardians who beat and strip her—ambivalence of societal gatekeepers over intimate love.

name: Solomon (son of David)
blurb: Royal figure anchoring the Song’s frame—owner of vineyards, bearer of the wedding crown, patron of wisdom and song (1 Kgs 4:32). He can be read as the bridegroom or as symbolic foil whose grandeur is
searchText: solomon (son of david) person royal royal figure anchoring the song’s frame—owner of vineyards, bearer of the wedding crown, patron of wisdom and song (1 kgs 4:32). he can be read as the bridegroom or as symbolic foil whose grandeur is relativized by the couple’s mutual love.

name: The Beloved (Shulammite woman)
blurb: Primary voice of the Song—dark yet lovely, vineyard worker turned garden of delight. She initiates pursuit (1:2–4), seeks at night (3:1–4), and claims mutual belonging (2:16; 6:3; 7:10). Background &
searchText: the beloved (shulammite woman) person character primary voice of the song—dark yet lovely, vineyard worker turned garden of delight. she initiates pursuit (1:2–4), seeks at night (3:1–4), and claims mutual belonging (2:16; 6:3; 7:10). background & solomon: the text names solomon (1:1; 3:7–11; 8:11–12) and portrays the bridegroom with royal imagery; some read the woman as **solomon’s beloved** (shulammite ≈ ‘shunammite’), others see her as independent of the king, even contrasting her personal vineyard with solomon’s commercial vineyard (8:11–12). either way, her agency and fidelity stand central—love is covenantal, voluntary, and resilient.

name: The Lover / Bridegroom
blurb: Speaks with shepherd and kingly tones—leaping over mountains, crafting palanquin, crowning day of wedding. Whether identified with Solomon or read as archetypal bridegroom, he models delighted, attent
searchText: the lover / bridegroom person character speaks with shepherd and kingly tones—leaping over mountains, crafting palanquin, crowning day of wedding. whether identified with solomon or read as archetypal bridegroom, he models delighted, attentive love.

name: Architecture & towers (Heshbon, Damascus)
blurb: Neck like the tower of David; nose like the tower of Lebanon—beauty pictured with civic strength; love builds, it does not merely adorn.
searchText: architecture & towers (heshbon, damascus) entity imagery neck like the tower of david; nose like the tower of lebanon—beauty pictured with civic strength; love builds, it does not merely adorn.

name: Body metaphors of beauty
blurb: Eyes as doves, hair like goats, neck as tower, teeth like shorn ewes; for him: head like gold, eyes like doves, legs like alabaster—metaphors dignify embodiment without pornographic gaze.
searchText: body metaphors of beauty entity imagery eyes as doves, hair like goats, neck as tower, teeth like shorn ewes; for him: head like gold, eyes like doves, legs like alabaster—metaphors dignify embodiment without pornographic gaze.

name: Canonical/typological horizons
blurb: Israel as YHWH’s bride; Christ and the Church as later reading—yet the literal marital sense remains the text’s primary register; typology arises from covenant patterns, not allegory alone.
searchText: canonical/typological horizons entity theology israel as yhwh’s bride; christ and the church as later reading—yet the literal marital sense remains the text’s primary register; typology arises from covenant patterns, not allegory alone.

name: ‘Catch for us the foxes’
blurb: Small threats spoil vineyards—early vigilance protects tender love; community (‘for us’) guards covenant joy.
searchText: ‘catch for us the foxes’ entity wisdom small threats spoil vineyards—early vigilance protects tender love; community (‘for us’) guards covenant joy.

name: City by night (search scenes)
blurb: Nocturnal quests dramatize desire and vulnerability; longing refuses apathy, risks misunderstanding to find the beloved.
searchText: city by night (search scenes) entity motif nocturnal quests dramatize desire and vulnerability; longing refuses apathy, risks misunderstanding to find the beloved.

name: Covenantal love: strong as death
blurb: Set me as a seal upon your heart and arm—the seal marks ownership and permanence; love’s flame is ‘a flame of YH’ (shalhevetyah). Many waters cannot quench love.
searchText: covenantal love: strong as death entity theology set me as a seal upon your heart and arm—the seal marks ownership and permanence; love’s flame is ‘a flame of yh’ (shalhevetyah). many waters cannot quench love.

name: Do not awaken love until it pleases (refrain)
blurb: Chastity refrain anchors timing—desire awaits proper season; love’s discipline enhances joy.
searchText: do not awaken love until it pleases (refrain) entity wisdom chastity refrain anchors timing—desire awaits proper season; love’s discipline enhances joy.

name: Garden locked, a spring sealed
blurb: Chastity and exclusivity: the bride as enclosed garden; love’s pleasures within covenant walls. Edenic echoes—pomegranates, spices, flowing waters.
searchText: garden locked, a spring sealed entity motif chastity and exclusivity: the bride as enclosed garden; love’s pleasures within covenant walls. edenic echoes—pomegranates, spices, flowing waters.

name: Mother’s house & maternal figures
blurb: Site of nurture and intimacy; the beloved longs to bring him to her mother’s house—love is embedded in family memory and blessing.
searchText: mother’s house & maternal figures entity family site of nurture and intimacy; the beloved longs to bring him to her mother’s house—love is embedded in family memory and blessing.

name: Mutuality and consent
blurb: ‘Draw me after you’; ‘I am my beloved’s and he is mine’—mutual belonging and initiative contrast with exploitative eros; desire is dialogical and dignifying.
searchText: mutuality and consent entity ethics ‘draw me after you’; ‘i am my beloved’s and he is mine’—mutual belonging and initiative contrast with exploitative eros; desire is dialogical and dignifying.

name: ‘My beloved is mine, and I am his’
blurb: Triple confession of mutual possession charts growth: from possession to priority (‘I am my beloved’s’).
searchText: ‘my beloved is mine, and i am his’ entity covenant triple confession of mutual possession charts growth: from possession to priority (‘i am my beloved’s’).

name: Season of singing (springtime)
blurb: Winter past, flowers appear, voice of the turtledove—creation’s renewal mirrors awakened love.
searchText: season of singing (springtime) entity season winter past, flowers appear, voice of the turtledove—creation’s renewal mirrors awakened love.

name: Song of Songs (which is Solomon’s)
blurb: The superlative ‘Song of Songs’ signals a collection of love poetry framed by Solomon’s name—either authorship, dedication, or Solomonic idiom. The book sanctifies marital desire within wisdom theolog
searchText: song of songs (which is solomon’s) entity editorial the superlative ‘song of songs’ signals a collection of love poetry framed by solomon’s name—either authorship, dedication, or solomonic idiom. the book sanctifies marital desire within wisdom theology.

name: ‘Turn, turn, O Shulammite’
blurb: Public gaze on private beauty—dance imagery raises questions of objectification vs celebration; the text leans toward covenant festivity guarded by consent.
searchText: ‘turn, turn, o shulammite’ entity poetry public gaze on private beauty—dance imagery raises questions of objectification vs celebration; the text leans toward covenant festivity guarded by consent.

name: Vineyard imagery (own vineyard vs Solomon’s)
blurb: Her ‘own vineyard’ (self/body/agency) contrasts with Solomon’s commercial vineyard with keepers—love resists commodification while inviting mutual enjoyment.
searchText: vineyard imagery (own vineyard vs solomon’s) entity motif her ‘own vineyard’ (self/body/agency) contrasts with solomon’s commercial vineyard with keepers—love resists commodification while inviting mutual enjoyment.

name: Wedding day & palanquin
blurb: Solomon’s litter with sixty warriors; mother crowns him on the day of gladness—public celebration of private covenant.
searchText: wedding day & palanquin entity wedding solomon’s litter with sixty warriors; mother crowns him on the day of gladness—public celebration of private covenant.

name: ‘Who is this coming up from the wilderness’
blurb: Exodus echoes—love emerges from wilderness into wedding. Salvation history becomes marriage imagery.
searchText: ‘who is this coming up from the wilderness’ entity theology exodus echoes—love emerges from wilderness into wedding. salvation history becomes marriage imagery.

name: ‘Your love is better than wine’
blurb: Opening prayer of desire—love surpasses luxury; the king brings her into his chambers, yet agency remains with the woman’s voice.
searchText: ‘your love is better than wine’ entity poetry opening prayer of desire—love surpasses luxury; the king brings her into his chambers, yet agency remains with the woman’s voice.
